Award.AwardTitle: EFRI 2-DARE: Crystalline Atomically Thin Layers for Photonic Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Description: The goals of this project are to synthesize atomically thin two-dimensional (2D) semiconducting layers, which possess novel properties often unavailable in their bulk counterparts, and incorporate them onto devices for novel photonic applications. Once demonstrated, these active and nonlinear photonic devices using 2D materials can potentially create a new paradigm of optoelectronics and may lead to numerous optical information and quantum information related applications. A multidisciplinary team from four academic institutions (Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Pennsylvania State University, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, and Washington University in St. Louis) is formed to investigate key research areas from 2D material synthesis, condensed matter theory, and optical engineering. This project also includes a comprehensive education and outreach plan at all levels, from encouraging underprivileged K-12 students into the exciting field of material sciences and optical engineering all the way up to faculty mentoring.

Technical Description: This project aims to predict, synthesize, characterize, and engineer semiconducting transition metal dichalcogenides (STMD) such as molybdenum and tungsten disulfides and diselenides, and utilize them to develop a new class of potentially transformative active and nonlinear photonic devices. A key challenge to develop high-quality 2D STMD materials is the control of these materials with predetermined thickness (number of layers), stacking and composition, and to tailor their optical properties for specific photonics applications. The synthesis strategy of this project is based on chemical vapor deposition (CVD), which has been proved suitable for synthesizing large-area (cm) 2D crystals of STMD, and for controlling the growth, clustering, doping, alloying and stacking of different STMD. The research team aims to establish a comprehensive first-principles framework for modeling the doping, alloying and stacking of a few layered STMD. The team develops more realistic approaches for the band structure (GW approximation) and excitonic behaviors by solving the Bethe-Salpeter equation. Such studies directly inform material design and CVD synthesis, and enable new photonic applications and devices based on STMD dressed fiber optics, plasmonic nanostructures, and micro-resonators. The research can potentially lead to new paradigms of STMD functionalized optoelectronics, with examples including parity-time symmetric systems for unidirectional invisibility, nonreciprocal light transmission, novel low-power optical switching and photon routing, ultra-low threshold lasers and amplifiers, TMD-plasmonic systems with nonlinear efficiency enhanced up to several orders of magnitude, and high-efficiency nonlinear/quantum optical devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes NSF EFRI-1334311

Four institutions participated in this project (Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Penn State University, Virginia Tech and Washington University St Louis) with research teams dedicated to theory, synthesis, characterization and device fabrication to investigate the nonlinear optical properties of ultrathin layered semiconducting nanomaterials known as transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) such as MoS2, WS2, MoSe2 and WSe2 for photonic applications. 

With respect to the theoretical thrust, first principles computer calculations were implemented to investigate the role of defects, strain, doping (substitute atoms in the structure) and molecular adsorption on TMDs when their thickness is about 1nm: A human hair is about 90,000 nm. At 1nm thickness the nonlinear optical response is the highest. It was found theoretically and confirmed experimentally that by introducing defects, doping or even adding water molecules to the surface of the TMDs, the presence of second harmonic generation (SHG), is not destroyed.  SHG is a nonlinear optical property that involves two incident photons (a quantum of light or a light particle) which after interacting with the TMDs, results in a single photon with twice the frequency of the initial photons (See figure 1), thus demonstrating the suitability to use this TMDs in nonlinear optical devices. Moreover, calculations were carried out to study the SHG of the TMDs under different types of strain finding for example that WSe2 is more sensitive to strain than WS2: this result has important implications when experimentally depositing the material in a substrate to fabricate a device. Theoretical results also were carried out in nanotubes out of TMDs, showing that SHG increases and can be tuned depending on the diameter of the nanotube.  

Regarding the synthesis thrust, the project made important advances in the thickness control and in the deposition of ultrathin TMDs on different substrates such as optical fibers and micro resonators (See figure 2).

Different methods based on powder vaporization and liquid phase precursors where improved and implemented. Moreover, the synthesis methods performed in this project allowed the doping of the TMDs to study their nonlinear optical response. Additionally, in collaboration with researchers of a different NSF-EFRI, layered materials were combined to produce heterostructures composed of one layer of WS2 and one layer of Bi2Te3. It was found that there is charged transfer between the layers and that the SHG is quenched. What is relevant in this point, is the possibility to explore other combination of layered materials which may be more suitable to improve the nonlinear optical behavior.      

The nonlinear optical characterization was carried out mainly by measuring the SHG and the sum frequency generation using an experimental setup with femtosecond lasers and digital holography.  In addition, other techniques such as Raman spectroscopy, photoluminescence, scanning electron microscopy and transmission electron microscopy were used. Defects in the samples were generated by ion bombardment and during the synthesis finding that the SHG response in the defective ultrathin materials continued being detected with high intensity while the photoluminescence was lost, thus confirming the robustness of the SHG and the suitability of TMDs for nonlinear optical devices.

The device fabrication team fabricated optical fibers and micro-resonators on which the ultrathin TMDs where deposited (see figure 2). Research will continue in this area.

With the support of this grant, 36 papers were published in peer reviewed scientific journals, five graduate students, partially supported by the grant, obtained their PhD. With additional support of the REM program of NSF (Research Experience and Mentoring) undergraduate students were introduced to research activities in 2-D materials, some of them from underrepresented minorities. Thanks to the EFRI gran, we were able to carry out a very successful program for high school students where the students could generate 3-D models using a 3-D printer. Moreover, participation in high school workshops was catalyzed by the grant.
